content:
Just got this in a clash and it's super easy for some languages, so I felt bad.

Ruby and Python don't need any 'BigInt' library to solve this, they can both just add the integers in any of your test cases without issue. Seems like this challenge really favours languages that can handle big integers natively. Solving the adder looks much harder than simply printing `bin(sum(int(_,2)+int(_,2)))`
This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "FASTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice contribution. It is suitable for all the modes. Verified the correctness in IDE. It completely works. Nice one by the way. `$><<$<.sum{|x|x.to_i(2)}.to_s(2)` This is my Ruby solution. It can be for both shortest and fastest modes. Mine might not be the shortest though

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: i like it

b=[...(r=readline)(a=[...r(o=0)].reverse())].reverse()
e=a.reduce((a,i,x)=>{(c=+b[x]+o+ +i,c>1?(c-=2,o=1):o=0);return a=c+a},'').split``
o>0?e.unshift(o):0
print(e.join``)

Without Bigint :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think it is a really good contribution:
Here is my solution (in python)
print(bin(int(input(),2)+int(input(),2)).replace('0b',''))

It can be good at fast mode and short code but also for reverse mode

a=int(input(),2)
b=int(input(),2)
x=a+b
print(f"{x:b}")

passes test 5 but not validator 5. I lack the understanding for a suggestion but test 5 should probably fail for the same reason as the validator here.
Output for Test 8 should be 10, not 11

I suggest to provide truth table not with the link but print it right in the description as ASCII-bordered table

Also maybe it's good to explicitly specify how to handle overflow (i.e. no clamping like some few machines actually do)

Inability to solve with "binary to decimal conversion" IMHO seems  obvious from testcases and constraints and thus may be not necessary to specify
My God!!! I added this last and haven't tested it !!! How much lack of attention !!! Thank you very much!

My mistake, I did not make it clear in the description that the number of bits in the output should be the same number of bits in A and B, unless there is carry out equal to 1, in this case output will have 1 bit more, in this case output will have 1 bit more. Your code eliminates the leading zeros.

I will change the test cases so that no one needs to handle exceptions.
Thank you Megha! Ruby is a very powerful language, you got really good at ruby this month!

Thanks @AndreMarasca. Yeah. I really love Ruby very much. So, I started practicing Ruby in all the coding sites I know like Leetcode, Exercism, etc. It was only because of Allis, I wanted to learn Ruby. Ruby has many basic and very common methods in standard library. Really thoughtful of Ruby :)
